name: Wyatt Castro
review: This particular model may look a little understated, but its materials, construction, finishing, and electronics package suggest otherwise, especially when it comes to coaxing some suitably impressive tones from it.

name: Madison Rivera
review: String and note volume across the whole neck is consistent, although the low B string's performance is a little woolly. Otherwise, the bass performs very well and should appeal to many players.

name: Barry Burke
review: it's enjoyable to play. With a few tweaks here and there, it could become more desirable.

name: Jackie Alvarez
review: It may look like a straightforward Grand Concert cutaway from the outside, but there's toneful innovation aplenty going on behind the scenes.

name: Alex Morris
review: In a marketplace where premium quality and tone often come at a king's ransom, the Furch stands out as being an upper-end instrument that would not drain the resources of a player serious about their sound.

name: Elaine Meyer
review: It might seem a bold statement to make this early on in a review, but we can honestly say that we've never played a bad Furch guitar since the brand first appeared on our radar many years ago.

name: Fernando Fuller
review: We're saying all this in advance in the interest of scene setting, because this guitar really is something rather special and we want to make sure that everyone is aware of where it sits in the marketplace before we zoom in for a closer look.

name: Alisa Parker
review: The Yellow Deluxe certainly feels good in the hands. The shape of the neck is an incredibly comfortable but at the same time very subtle V.

name: Eduardo Hart
review: You might barely notice their presence, but they certainly enhance the playing experience, particularly if you're looking at a long evening's set of material.

name: Laurie Richards
review: There's enough volume to fill a room, and for live use, while our review sample came without a pickup, we're told that Furch offers a range of options on this front, including the trusty LR Baggs Anthem or Element systems.

name: Jamie Soto
review: More robust, more player-friendly and sensibly priced, this big-bodied electric from the Electromatic series is a born crowd-pleaser.

name: Anna Ramos
review: The new collection of Electromatics includes a slew of Classic Hollow Bodies, a Jet BT, Jet Baritone, a short-scale Junior Jet II bass guitar and even a Lap Steel, all in wildly cool and arresting finishes.
